001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.glutils.ShaderProgram;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorfulBatch;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorfulSprite;
008
009/**
010 * Constants that contain the critical shader code to construct a {@link ShaderProgram} that can render the rest of this
011 * library. The shader code is meant for use in a {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch}; a convenience
012 * method, {@link #makeBatch()}, is provided to generate and return a SpriteBatch that uses the correct ShaderProgram.
013 * <br>
014 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 12/2/2019.
015 */
016public class Shaders {
017    /**
018     * This is the default vertex shader from libGDX.
019     */
020    public static final String vertexShader = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
021            + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
022            + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
023            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
024            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
025            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
026            + "\n"
027            + "void main()\n"
028            + "{\n"
029            + "   v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
030            + "   v_color.a = v_color.a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
031            + "   v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
032            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
033            + "}\n";
034    /**
035     * A simple shader that uses additive blending with "normal" RGBA colors (alpha is still multiplicative).
036     * With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram, white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%,
037     * and black darkens a color to black, but nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color,
038     * white adds 0.5 to the RGB channels (brightening it and also desaturating it), and black subtracts 0.5 from the
039     * RGB channels (darkening and desaturating, but not to black unless the color is already somewhat dark). When
040     * tinting with white, this looks like <a href="https://i.imgur.com/iAb1rig.png">The Mona Lisa on the left</a>, when
041     * tinting with 50% gray, it makes no change, and when tinting with black, it almost reaches all black, but some
042     * faint part of the image is still barely visible.
043     */
044    public static final String fragmentShaderRGBA =
045            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
046                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
047                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
048                    "#else\n" +
049                    "#define LOWP \n" +
050                    "#endif\n" +
051                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
052                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
053                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
054                    "void main()\n" +
055                    "{\n" +
056                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
057                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(tgt.rgb * pow((v_color.rgb + 0.1) * 1.666, vec3(1.5)), v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
058                    "}";
059    /**
060     * A simple shader that uses multiplicative blending with "normal" RGBA colors, but internally uses gamma correction
061     * to make changes in color smoother. With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram, white is the neutral color, 50%
062     * gray darkens a color by about 50%, and black darkens a color to black, but nothing can brighten a color. With
063     * this, 50% gray is the neutral color, white multiplies the RGB channels by about 2 (brightening it and slightly
064     * desaturating it), and black multiplies the RGB channels by 0 (reducing the color always to black). When tinting
065     * with white, this looks like <a href="https://i.imgur.com/gKRSzKv.png">The Mona Lisa on the left</a>; when tinting
066     * with 50% gray, it makes no change, and when tinting with black, it produces an all-black image.
067     * <br>
068     * Credit for finding this goes to CypherCove, who uses a similar version in
069     * <a href="https://github.com/CypherCove/gdx-tween/blob/5047eeae9250d1f1c52e87aaf572956045a523f9/gdx-tween/src/main/java/com/cyphercove/gdxtween/graphics/GtColor.java">gdx=tween</a>.
070     */
071    public static final String fragmentShaderGammaRGBA =
072            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
073                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
074                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
075                    "#else\n" +
076                    "#define LOWP \n" +
077                    "#endif\n" +
078                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
079                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
080                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
081                    "void main()\n" +
082                    "{\n" +
083                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n" +
084                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(sqrt(tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb * v_color.rgb * v_color.rgb * 4.0), v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
085                    "}";
086    //// save the result as shader, and set it on your batch with
087    // ShaderProgram shader = makeRGBAShader();
088    // batch.setShader(shader)
089    /**
090     * A simple helper method that builds the simplest shader here; this shader allows tinting with light colors to
091     * lighten an image. You can assign the result to a SpriteBatch with its
092     * {@link SpriteBatch#setShader(ShaderProgram)} method.
093     * @return a ShaderProgram that uses the RGBA shader {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA}
094     */
095    public static ShaderProgram makeRGBAShader()
096    {
097        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderRGBA);
098        if(!shader.isCompiled())
099            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
100        return shader;
101    }
102    /**
103     * A simple helper method that builds the simplest shader here; this shader allows tinting with light colors to
104     * lighten an image, and also smooths changes well. You can assign the result to a SpriteBatch with its
105     * {@link SpriteBatch#setShader(ShaderProgram)} method.
106     * @return a ShaderProgram that uses the RGBA shader {@link #fragmentShaderGammaRGBA}
107     */
108    public static ShaderProgram makeGammaRGBAShader()
109    {
110        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderGammaRGBA);
111        if(!shader.isCompiled())
112            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
113        return shader;
114    }
115
116    /**
117     * Where the magic happens; this converts a batch color from the YCwCm format (used by colorful) to RGBA.
118     * The vertex color will be split up into 4 channels just as a normal shader does, but the channels here are
119     * luma, chromatic warmth, chromatic mildness, and alpha; alpha acts just like a typical RGBA shader, but the others
120     * are additive instead of multiplicative, with 0.5 as a neutral value. This does not support the "tweak" features
121     * that {@link ColorfulBatch} does, which include multiplicative counterparts to the additive operations this
122     * supports on luma, chromatic warmth, and chromatic mildness, plus a contrast adjustment. If you want to adjust
123     * contrast globally, you can use {@link #makeBatch(float)} to set the contrast for a new Batch with a new shader.
124     */
125    public static final String fragmentShader =
126            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
127                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
128                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
129                    "#else\n" +
130                    "#define LOWP \n" +
131                    "#endif\n" +
132                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
133                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
134                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
135//                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.75, 1.0, 0.25);\n" +
136                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125);\n" +
137                    "void main()\n" +
138                    "{\n" +
139                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
140                    //use the following line to match the color exactly
141                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r - 0.5 + dot(tgt.rgb, bright), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
142                    //use the following line to increase contrast
143//                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r * dot(sin(tgt.rgb * 1.5707963267948966) * sqrt(tgt.rgb), bright), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
144                    //use the following line to increase contrast more
145//                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, bright), 1.25), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
146
147                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(dot(ycc, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)), dot(ycc, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)), dot(ycc, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)), v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
148                    "}";
149    /**
150     * A variant on {@link #fragmentShader} that adjusts luma to make mid-range colors darker, while keeping light
151     * colors light. This is not the same as {@link ColorfulBatch} even when the contrast for ColorfulBatch's tweak is
152     * the same as what this uses (1.375 here, which is roughly 0.875f in a tweak value). ColorfulBatch does some work
153     * in the vertex shader so it may be a little faster than this approach, and it seems to have less severe effects on
154     * the overall brightness of an image that has adjusted contrast.
155     */
156    public static final String fragmentShaderHigherContrast =
157            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
158                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
159                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
160                    "#else\n" +
161                    "#define LOWP \n" +
162                    "#endif\n" +
163                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
164                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
165                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
166                    "const float contrast =    1.375   ;\n" + // you can make contrast a uniform if you want
167                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125) * (4.0 / 3.0);\n" +
168                    "void main()\n" +
169                    "{\n" +
170                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
171                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r - 0.5 + pow(dot(tgt.rgb, bright), contrast) * 0.75, ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
172                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(dot(ycc, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)), dot(ycc, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)), dot(ycc, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)), v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
173                    "}";
174
175    /**
176     * An alternative shader that effectively reduces luma contrast, bringing all but the darkest colors to the
177     * upper-mid luma range. This is not the same as {@link ColorfulBatch} even when the contrast for ColorfulBatch's
178     * tweak is the same as what this uses (0.625 here, which is roughly 0.125f in a tweak value). ColorfulBatch does
179     * some work in the vertex shader so it may be a little faster than this approach, and it seems to have less severe
180     * effects on the overall brightness of an image that has adjusted contrast.
181     */
182    public static final String fragmentShaderLowerContrast = fragmentShaderHigherContrast.replace("   1.375   ", "0.625");
183
184    /**
185     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses the default {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShader}
186     * from this class, making it able to render YCwCm colors from the rest of this library. It won't be a
187     * {@link ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways); you can simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to
188     * make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch won't be able to render a {@link ColorfulSprite}, but ColorfulBatch
189     * can.
190     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
191     */
192    public static SpriteBatch makeBatch()
193    {
194        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShader);
195        if(!shader.isCompiled())
196            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
197        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
198    }
199
200    /**
201     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses the default {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShader}
202     * from this class, making it able to render YCwCm colors from the rest of this library. This also takes a
203     * {@code contrast} parameter; if greater than 1.0 it will make light colors lighter and dark colors darker, while
204     * if it is less than 1.0 it will make all but the darkest colors closer to the upper-middle-range of lightness.
205     * If you want to adjust contrast per-sprite, use a {@link ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways);
206     * you can simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch won't be able
207     * to render a {@link ColorfulSprite}, but ColorfulBatch can. ColorfulBatch also will calculate contrast differently
208     * from the shader this uses, including doing some work in the vertex shader (which may be faster). It also takes a
209     * contrast in its tweak value that is limited to a 0.0 to 1.0 range, rather than 0.1 to 2.0 here (this can
210     * technically tolerate 0.01 to 10.0, but those extremes aren't recommended).
211     * @param contrast how much contrast should be emphasized; higher than 1.0 is more contrasting, and this should usually be between 0.1 and 2.0
212     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
213     */
214    public static SpriteBatch makeBatch(final float contrast)
215    {
216        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderHigherContrast.replace("   1.375   ", Float.toString(Math.min(Math.max(contrast, 0.01f), 10f))));
217        if(!shader.isCompiled())
218            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
219        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
220    }
221
222    /**
223     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses {@link #vertexShaderHSLC} and {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}
224     * from this class, making it interpret the SpriteBatch's color, as set by 
225     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, to be hue rotation, saturation change, lightness
226     * change, and contrast change. All of these are neutral when their value is 0.5f. Hue rotates clockwise or
227     * counterclockwise when it goes toward 0.0, and the other way when it goes toward 1.0; 0.0 and 1.0 both refer to
228     * the 180 degree rotation, but I don't know which goes which way (it also depends on how you visualize hue).
229     * Saturation becomes more grayscale as it goes towards 0.0, and more vivid as it goes towards 1.0. Lightness gets
230     * darker towards 0.0, lighter towards 1.0 (any lightness above 0.5 will brighten the image, unlike the default
231     * shader and batch color). Contrast affects changes in lightness; low contrast makes all lightness closer to the
232     * mid-range, while high contrast makes even small changes in the mid-range of an image's color have stark lightness
233     * changes in the result.
234     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
235     */
236    public static SpriteBatch makeBatchHSLC()
237    {
238        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShaderHSLC, fragmentShaderHSLC);
239        if(!shader.isCompiled())
240            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
241        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
242    }
243
244    /**
245     * Similar to {@link #fragmentShader}, but this uses the very perceptually-accurate IPT color space as described by
246     * Ebner and Fairchild, instead of the custom YCwCm color space. IPT doesn't really need that much more computation
247     * to be done by the shader, but tends to make gradual changes in color much smoother. If comparing to YCwCm, then
248     * Y (luma) is like I (intensity) here, so when a Batch color has 0 for I (stored in the r channel), it makes the
249     * image very dark, while if the Batch color has 1 for I, it makes the image very light. Cw and Cm can be graphed
250     * like a color wheel, and in their case, the 4 corners of a square graph are red, yellow, green, and blue. IPT is
251     * less geometrical, and the corners are roughly purple, orange, green, and cyan, while the centers of the edges of
252     * the square are close to red, yellow, green, and blue. <a href="https://i.imgur.com/A3n4qmM.png">See this capture
253     * of the IPT space</a> if you want a better picture. The P (short for protan, a term from ophthalmology) channel
254     * (stored in g) is the left-to-right axis there, with P==0 making colors green or blue (cooler), and P==1 making
255     * colors orange, red, or purple (somewhat warmer). The T (short for tritan, also from ophthalmology) channel
256     * (stored in b) is the down-to-up axis there, with T==0 making colors more blue or purple, and T==1 making colors
257     * more green, yellow, brown, or orange. Where protan can be viewed as going from cool to warm as its value
258     * increases, tritan can be viewed as going from artificial to natural, or perhaps fluid to solid. Alpha is treated
259     * exactly as it is in the standard libGDX fragment shader, with the alpha in the batch color multiplied by the
260     * alpha in the image pixel to get the result alpha.
261     */
262    public static String fragmentShaderIPT =
263            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
264                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
265                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
266                    "#else\n" +
267                    "#define LOWP \n" +
268                    "#endif\n" +
269                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
270                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
271                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
272                    "void main()\n" +
273                    "{\n" +
274                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
275                    "    vec4 adj = v_color;\n" +
276                    "    adj.yz = adj.yz * 2.0 - 0.5;\n" +
277                    "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
278                    "         * (tgt.rgb)) + adj.xyz - 0.5;\n" +
279                    "    ipt.x = clamp(ipt.x, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
280                    "    ipt.yz = clamp(ipt.yz, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
281                    "    vec3 back = mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt;\n" +
282                    "    gl_FragColor = vec4(clamp(back, 0.0, 1.0), adj.a * tgt.a);\n" +
283                    "}";
284    /**
285     * Just like {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}, but gamma-corrects the input and output RGB values (which improves
286     * lightness uniformity) and uses an exponential step internally to change how colors are distributed within the
287     * gamut. These steps are more computationally expensive than the bare-bones ones in {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}, but
288     * they seem to improve some aspects of color transitions quite a bit.
289     */
290    public static String fragmentShaderIPT_HQ =
291            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
292                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
293                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
294                    "#else\n" +
295                    "#define LOWP \n" +
296                    "#endif\n" +
297                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
298                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
299                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
300                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(0.43);\n" +
301                    "const vec3 reverse = vec3(1.0 / 0.43);\n" +
302                    "void main()\n" +
303                    "{\n" +
304                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
305                    "  vec3 ipt = mat3(0.40000, 4.45500, 0.80560, 0.40000, -4.8510, 0.35720, 0.20000, 0.39600, -1.1628) *" +
306                    "             pow(mat3(0.313921, 0.151693, 0.017753, 0.639468, 0.748209, 0.109468, 0.0465970, 0.1000044, 0.8729690) \n" +
307                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
308                    "  ipt.x = clamp(ipt.x + v_color.x - 0.55, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
309                    "  ipt.yz = clamp(ipt.yz + v_color.yz * 2.0 - 1.0, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
310                    "  ipt = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.097569, -0.11388, 0.032615, 0.205226, 0.133217, -0.67689) * ipt;\n" +
311                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
312                    "                 mat3(5.432622, -1.10517, 0.028104, -4.67910, 2.311198, -0.19466, 0.246257, -0.20588, 1.166325) *\n" +
313                    "                 (sign(ipt) * pow(abs(ipt), reverse))," +
314                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
315                    "}";
316
317    /**
318     * Just like {@link #fragmentShaderIPT_HQ}, but uses the Oklab color space instead of the very similar IPT_HQ one.
319     */
320    public static String fragmentShaderOklab =
321            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
322                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
323                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
324                    "#else\n" +
325                    "#define LOWP \n" +
326                    "#endif\n" +
327                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
328                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
329                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
330                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n" +
331                    "void main()\n" +
332                    "{\n" +
333                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
334                    "  vec3 lab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *" +
335                    "             pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n" +
336                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
337                    "  lab.x = clamp(lab.x + v_color.r - 0.63, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
338                    "  lab.yz = clamp(lab.yz + v_color.gb * 2.0 - 1.0, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
339                    "  lab = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, +0.3963377774, -0.1055613458, -0.0894841775, +0.2158037573, -0.0638541728, -1.2914855480) * lab;\n" +
340                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
341                    "                 mat3(+4.0767245293, -1.2681437731, -0.0041119885, -3.3072168827, +2.6093323231, -0.7034763098, +0.2307590544, -0.3411344290, +1.7068625689) *\n" +
342                    "                 (lab * lab * lab)," +
343                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
344                    "}";
345
346    /**
347     * A vertex shader that does the bulk of processing HSI-format batch colors and converting them to a format
348     * {@link #fragmentShaderHSI} can use. Since HSI is only a cylindrical/spherical adaptation of IPT, with identical
349     * I components and the combination of H and S in polar coordinates mapping to P and T in Cartesian coordinates,
350     * the fragment shader this is used with can be any that expects an IPT color (currently only
351     * {@link #fragmentShaderIPT} does this, and it's the same as {@link #fragmentShaderHSI}). This vertex shader does
352     * a lot more than most vertex shaders here, but since it is executed relatively rarely (unless you're drawing many
353     * 1-pixel textures), there shouldn't be a heavy performance penalty.
354     */
355    public static final String vertexShaderHSI = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
356        + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
357        + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
358        + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
359        + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
360        + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
361        + "const vec3 yellow  = vec3( 0.16155326,0.020876605,-0.26078433 );\n"
362        + "const vec3 magenta = vec3(-0.16136102,0.122068435,-0.070396   );\n"
363        + "const vec3 cyan    = vec3( 0.16420607,0.3481738,   0.104959644);\n"
364        + "void main()\n"
365        + "{\n"
366        + "    v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
367        + "    v_color.a = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ".a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
368        + "    vec3 hsi = v_color.rgb;\n"
369        + "    v_color.x = (hsi.z - 0.5) * 0.9999;\n"
370        + "    hsi.x *= 6.28318;\n"
371        + "    hsi.y *= 0.5;\n"
372        + "    v_color.y = cos(hsi.x) * hsi.y;\n"
373        + "    v_color.z = sin(hsi.x) * hsi.y;\n"
374        + "    float crMid = dot(cyan.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
375        + "    float mgMid = dot(magenta.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
376        + "    float ybMid = dot(yellow.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
377        + "    float crScale = (v_color.x - 0.5 + step(crMid, 0.0)) * cyan.x / (0.00001 - crMid);\n"
378        + "    float mgScale = (v_color.x + 0.5 - step(mgMid, 0.0)) * magenta.x / (0.00001 - mgMid);\n"
379        + "    float ybScale = (v_color.x - 0.5 + step(ybMid, 0.0)) * yellow.x / (0.00001 - ybMid);\n"
380        + "    float scale = 4.0 * min(crScale, min(mgScale, ybScale));\n"
381        + "    v_color.yz *= scale * length(v_color.yz) / cos(3.14159 * v_color.x);\n"
382        + "    v_color.xyz += 0.5;\n"
383        + "    v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
384        + "    gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
385        + "}\n";
386    public static String fragmentShaderHSI = fragmentShaderIPT;
387
388    /**
389     * Credit to Sam Hocevar, https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/a/59808 .
390     */
391    public static final String partialCodeHSL =
392            "const float eps = 1.0e-10;\n" +
393//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
394//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
395//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
396//                    "    return  hue * (  2.137\n" +
397//                    "          + hue * (  0.542\n" +
398//                    "          + hue * (-15.141\n" +
399//                    "          + hue * ( 30.120\n" +
400//                    "          + hue * (-22.541\n" +
401//                    "          + hue *   5.883)))));\n" +
402//                    "}\n" +
403//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
404//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
405//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
406//                    "    return  hue * (  0.677\n" +
407//                    "          + hue * ( -0.123\n" +
408//                    "          + hue * (-11.302\n" +
409//                    "          + hue * ( 46.767\n" +
410//                    "          + hue * (-58.493\n" +
411//                    "          + hue *   23.474)))));\n" +
412//                    "}\n" +
413                    "vec4 rgb2hsl(vec4 c)\n" +
414                    "{\n" +
415                    "    const vec4 J = vec4(0.0, -1.0 / 3.0, 2.0 / 3.0, -1.0);\n" +
416                    "    vec4 p = mix(vec4(c.bg, J.wz), vec4(c.gb, J.xy), step(c.b, c.g));\n" +
417                    "    vec4 q = mix(vec4(p.xyw, c.r), vec4(c.r, p.yzx), step(p.x, c.r));\n" +
418                    "    float d = q.x - min(q.w, q.y);\n" +
419                    "    float l = q.x * (1.0 - 0.5 * d / (q.x + eps));\n" +
420                    "    return vec4(abs(q.z + (q.w - q.y) / (6.0 * d + eps)), (q.x - l) / (min(l, 1.0 - l) + eps), l, c.a);\n" +
421                    "}\n" +
422                    "\n" +
423                    "vec4 hsl2rgb(vec4 c)\n" +
424                    "{\n" +
425                    "    const vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);\n" +
426                    "    vec3 p = abs(fract(c.x + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);\n" +
427                    "    float v = (c.z + c.y * min(c.z, 1.0 - c.z));\n" +
428                    "    return vec4(v * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), 2.0 * (1.0 - c.z / (v + eps))), c.w);\n" +
429                    "}";
430
431    /**
432     * Adjusted-hue version of {@link #partialCodeHSL}, supplying HSL to-and-from RGB conversions with a smaller range
433     * of hue used for cyan and a larger range for orange. Not currently used. Credit to Sam Hocevar,
434     * https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/a/59808 .
435     */
436    public static final String partialCodeHSLStretched =
437            "const float eps = 1.0e-10;\n" +
438                    //// maybe not blue enough?
439//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
440//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
441//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
442//                    "    return  hue * (  1.630\n" +

444//                    "          + hue * (-38.485\n" +
445//                    "          + hue * ( 76.101\n" +
446//                    "          + hue * (-63.977\n" +
447//                    "          + hue *   19.794)))));\n" +
448//                    "}\n" +
449//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
450//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
451//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
452//                    "    return  hue * (  1.463\n" +
453//                    "          + hue * ( -9.834\n" +
454//                    "          + hue * ( 31.153\n" +
455//                    "          + hue * (-35.066\n" +
456//                    "          + hue *   13.284))));\n" +
457//                    "}\n" +
458                    //// still weirdly high orange
459//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
460//                    "    return  hue * (  2.634\n" +
461//                    "          + hue * ( -4.703\n" +
462//                    "          + hue * (  3.659\n" +
463//                    "          + hue * (  0.829\n" +
464//                    "          + hue *   -1.419))));\n" +
465//                    "}\n" +
466//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
467//                    "    return  hue * (  1.163\n" +
468//                    "          + hue * ( -7.102\n" +
469//                    "          + hue * ( 22.709\n" +
470//                    "          + hue * (-25.502\n" +
471//                    "          + hue *    9.732))));\n" +
472//                    "}\n" +
473//                    "const float ROOT   = 16.0;\n" +
474//                    "const float SQUARE = ROOT * ROOT;\n" +
475                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
476//                    "    return (sqrt(hue * 0.9375 + 0.0625) - 0.25) * 1.333;\n" +
477//                    "    return asin(sqrt(hue * SQUARE) * (1.0 / ROOT)) * (2.0 * 3.14159274);\n" +
478
479//                    "    return asin((sqrt(hue * 0.9375 + 0.0625) - 0.25) * 2.666 - 1.0) * 0.318309886 + 0.5;\n" +
480
481//                    "    return sqrt(sin((hue - 0.5) * 3.14159274) * 0.5 + 0.5);\n" +
482//                    "    return pow(hue, 0.5625);\n" +
483//                    "    return sqrt(hue);\n" +
484                    "    return (sqrt(hue + 0.050625) - 0.225) * 1.25;\n" +
485                    "}\n" +
486                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
487//                    "    hue = sin((hue) * (0.5 * 3.14159274));\n" +
488//                    "    hue = (hue) * 0.75 + 0.25;\n" +
489                    
490//                    "    hue = sin((hue - 0.5) * 3.14159274);\n" +
491//                    "    hue = (hue + 1.0) * 0.375 + 0.25;\n" +
492//                    "    return (hue * hue - 0.0625) * (1.0 / 0.9375);\n" +
493                    
494//                    "    return asin(hue * hue * 2.0 - 1.0) * 0.318309886 + 0.5;\n" +
495//                    "    return pow(hue, 1.77777);\n" +
496                    "    return pow(hue * 0.8 + 0.225, 2.0) - 0.050625;\n" +
497//                    "    return hue * hue;\n" +
498
499//                    "    hue = sin((hue) * (0.5 * 3.14159274));\n" +
500//                    "    hue = hue * ROOT;\n" +
501//                    "    return (hue * hue) * (1.0 / SQUARE);\n" +
502
503                    "}\n" +
504                    //// way too much orange?
505//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
506//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
507//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
508//                    "    return  hue * (  2.137\n" +
509//                    "          + hue * (  0.542\n" +
510//                    "          + hue * (-15.141\n" +
511//                    "          + hue * ( 30.120\n" +
512//                    "          + hue * (-22.541\n" +
513//                    "          + hue *    5.883)))));\n" +
514//                    "}\n" +
515//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
516//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
517//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
518//                    "    return  hue * (  0.677\n" +
519//                    "          + hue * ( -0.123\n" +
520//                    "          + hue * (-11.302\n" +
521//                    "          + hue * ( 46.767\n" +
522//                    "          + hue * (-58.493\n" +
523//                    "          + hue *   23.474)))));\n" +
524//                    "}\n" +
525                    "vec4 rgb2hsl(vec4 c)\n" +
526                    "{\n" +
527                    "    const vec4 J = vec4(0.0, -1.0 / 3.0, 2.0 / 3.0, -1.0);\n" +
528                    "    vec4 p = mix(vec4(c.bg, J.wz), vec4(c.gb, J.xy), step(c.b, c.g));\n" +
529                    "    vec4 q = mix(vec4(p.xyw, c.r), vec4(c.r, p.yzx), step(p.x, c.r));\n" +
530                    "\n" +
531                    "    float d = q.x - min(q.w, q.y);\n" +
532                    "    float l = q.x * (1.0 - 0.5 * d / (q.x + eps));\n" +
533                    "    return vec4(official2primaries(abs(q.z + (q.w - q.y) / (6.0 * d + eps))), (q.x - l) / (min(l, 1.0 - l) + eps), l, c.a);\n" +
534                    "}\n" +
535                    "\n" +
536                    "vec4 hsl2rgb(vec4 c)\n" +
537                    "{\n" +
538                    "    const vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);\n" +
539                    "    vec3 p = abs(fract(primaries2official(c.x) + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);\n" +
540                    "    float v = (c.z + c.y * min(c.z, 1.0 - c.z));\n" +
541                    "    return vec4(v * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), 2.0 * (1.0 - c.z / (v + eps))), c.w);\n" +
542                    "}";
543
544    public static final String fragmentShaderHSL =
545            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
546                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
547                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
548                    "#else\n" +
549                    "#define LOWP \n" +
550                    "#endif\n" +
551                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
552                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
553                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
554                    partialCodeHSL +
555                    "void main()\n" +
556                    "{\n" +
557                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
558                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
559                    "   hsl.x = fract((fract(v_color.x + 0.5 - hsl.x) - 0.5) * v_color.w + hsl.x);\n" +
560                    "   hsl.yz = mix(hsl.yz, v_color.yz, v_color.w);\n" +
561                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
562                    "}";
563    
564    public static final String fragmentShaderRotateHSL =
565            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
566                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
567                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
568                    "#else\n" +
569                    "#define LOWP \n" +
570                    "#endif\n" +
571                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
572                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
573                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
574                    partialCodeHSL +
575                    "void main()\n" +
576                    "{\n" +
577                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
578                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
579                    "   hsl.x = fract(v_color.x + hsl.x + 0.5);\n" +
580                    "   hsl.yz = clamp(hsl.yz * v_color.yz * 2.0, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
581                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
582                    "}";

584    /**
585     * This is the default vertex shader from libGDX, but also sets a varying value for contrast. It is needed if you
586     * use {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}.
587     */
588    public static final String vertexShaderHSLC = "attribute vec4 a_position;\n"
589            + "attribute vec4 a_color;\n"
590            + "attribute vec2 a_texCoord0;\n"
591            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
592            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
593            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" 
594            + "varying float v_lightFix;\n"
595            + "\n"
596            + "void main()\n"
597            + "{\n"
598            + "   v_color = a_color;\n"
599            + "   v_texCoords = a_texCoord0;\n"
600            + "   v_color.a = pow(v_color.a * (255.0/254.0) + 0.5, 1.709);\n"    
601            + "   v_lightFix = 1.0 + pow(v_color.a, 1.41421356);\n"
602            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * a_position;\n"
603            + "}\n";
604
605    /**
606     * Allows changing Hue/Saturation/Lightness/Contrast, with hue as a rotation. Expects the vertex shader to be
607     * {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so contrast can use it.
608     * <br>
609     * Credit for HLSL version goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
610     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
611     * The YCC adaptation, and different approach to contrast (this has close to neutral contrast when a is 0.5,
612     * while the original had a fair bit higher contrast than expected), is from this codebase.
613     */
614    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC = 
615                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
616                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
617                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
618                    "#else\n" +
619                    "#define LOWP \n" +
620                    "#endif\n" +
621                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
622                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
623                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
624                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
625                    "vec3 applyHue(vec3 rgb, float hue)\n" +
626                    "{\n" +
627                    "    vec3 k = vec3(0.57735);\n" +
628                    "    float c = cos(hue);\n" +
629                    "    //Rodrigues' rotation formula\n" +
630                    "    return rgb * c + cross(k, rgb) * sin(hue) + k * dot(k, rgb) * (1.0 - c);\n" +
631                    "}\n" +
632                    "void main()\n" +
633                    "{\n" +
634                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
635                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
636                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
637                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
638                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
639                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
640                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix + brightness),\n" + // lightness
641                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
642                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
643                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
644                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
645                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
646                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
647                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
648                    "}";
649    /**
650     * Allows changing Hue/Saturation/Lightness/Alpha, with hue as a rotation. Expects the vertex shader to be
651     * {@link #vertexShader}, unlike what {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} expects.
652     * <br>
653     * Credit for HLSL version goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
654     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
655     * The YCC adaptation, and change to use alpha, is from this codebase.
656     */
657    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLA = 
658                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
659                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
660                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
661                    "#else\n" +
662                    "#define LOWP \n" +
663                    "#endif\n" +
664                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
665                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
666                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
667                    "vec3 applyHue(vec3 rgb, float hue)\n" +
668                    "{\n" +
669                    "    vec3 k = vec3(0.57735);\n" +
670                    "    float c = cos(hue);\n" +
671                    "    //Rodrigues' rotation formula\n" +
672                    "    return rgb * c + cross(k, rgb) * sin(hue) + k * dot(k, rgb) * (1.0 - c);\n" +
673                    "}\n" +
674                    "void main()\n" +
675                    "{\n" +
676                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
677                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
678                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
679                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
680                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
681                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
682                    "     (dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)) + brightness),\n" + // lightness
683                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
684                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
685                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
686                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
687                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
688                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
689                    "     tgt.a * v_color.w), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
690                    "}";
691    /**
692     * GLSL: Takes an RGB vec3 and a float that represents a hue rotation in radians, and returns the rotated RGB vec3.
693     * Credit for this challenging method goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
694     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
695     */
696    public static final String hueRodrigues =
697            "vec3 applyHue(vec3 rgb, float hue)\n" +
698            "{\n" +
699            "    vec3 k = vec3(0.57735);\n" +
700            "    float c = cos(hue);\n" +
701            "    //Rodrigues' rotation formula\n" +
702            "    return rgb * c + cross(k, rgb) * sin(hue) + k * dot(k, rgb) * (1.0 - c);\n" +
703            "}\n";
704
705    /**
706     * Generally a lower-quality hue rotation than {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}; this is here as a work in progress.
707     * Expects the vertex shader to be {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so
708     * contrast can use it.
709     */
710    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC2 = 
711                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
712                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
713                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
714                    "#else\n" +
715                    "#define LOWP \n" +
716                    "#endif\n" +
717                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
718                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
719                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
720                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
721                            partialCodeHSL +
722                    "void main()\n" +
723                    "{\n" +
724                    "    float hue = (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
725                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
726                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
727                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
728                    "    tgt = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
729                    "    tgt.r = fract(tgt.r + hue);\n" +
730                    "    tgt = hsl2rgb(tgt);\n" +
731                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
732                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix + brightness),\n" + // lightness
733                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
734                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
735                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
736                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
737                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
738                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
739                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
740                    "}";
741    /**
742     * Cycles lightness in a psychedelic way as hue and lightness change; not a general-purpose usage.
743     * Expects the vertex shader to be {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so
744     * contrast can use it.
745     */
746    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC3 =
747            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
748                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
749                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
750                    "#else\n" +
751                    "#define LOWP \n" +
752                    "#endif\n" +
753                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
754                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
755                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
756                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
757                    "vec3 applyHue(vec3 rgb, float hue)\n" +
758                    "{\n" +
759                    "    vec3 k = vec3(0.57735);\n" +
760                    "    float c = cos(hue);\n" +
761                    "    //Rodrigues' rotation formula\n" +
762                    "    return rgb * c + cross(k, rgb) * sin(hue) + k * dot(k, rgb) * (1.0 - c);\n" +
763                    "}\n" +
764                    "void main()\n" +
765                    "{\n" +
766                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
767                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
768                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
769                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
770                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
771                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
772                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix),\n" + // lightness
773                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
774                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
775                    "    tgt.r = sin((tgt.r + brightness) * 6.2831853) * 0.5 + 0.5;\n" +
776                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
777                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
778                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
779                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
780                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
781                    "}";
782    /**
783     * Cycles hue, but not lightness; otherwise this is like {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC3} without contrast, and keeping
784     * alpha intact.
785     * Internally, this uses Sam Hocevar's RGB/HSL conversion instead of Andrey-Postelzhuk's HSLC code.
786     * Expects the vertex shader to be {@link #vertexShader}, not the HSLC variant.
787     */
788    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLPsychedelic =
789            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
790                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
791                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
792                    "#else\n" +
793                    "#define LOWP \n" +
794                    "#endif\n" +
795                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
796                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
797                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
798                    partialCodeHSL +
799                    "void main()\n" +
800                    "{\n" +
801                    "    float hue = v_color.x - 0.5;\n" +
802                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
803                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
804                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
805                    "    tgt = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
806                    "    tgt.x = fract(tgt.x + hue);\n" +
807                    "    tgt.y = clamp(tgt.y * saturation, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
808                    "    tgt.z = clamp(brightness + tgt.z, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
809                    "    gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(tgt);\n" +
810                    "}";
811
812    /**
813     * One of the more useful HSL shaders here, this takes a batch color as hue, saturation, lightness, and power,
814     * with hue as a target hue and power used to determine how much of the target color should be used. There is no
815     * neutral value for hue, saturation, or lightness, but if power is 0, then the source color will be used
816     * exactly. On the other hand, if power is 1.0, then all pixels will be the target color. Hue is specified from
817     * 0.0 to 1.0, with 0.0 as red, about 0.3 as green, about 0.6 as blue, etc. Saturation is specified from 0.0 to 1.0,
818     * with 0.0 as grayscale and 1.0 as a fully-saturated target color. Lightness is specified from 0.0 to 1.0, with 0.0
819     * as black, the 0.3 to 0.7 range as most colors, and 1.0 white; saturation is clamped to a smaller value as
820     * lightness moves away from 0.5 (toward black or white).
821     */
822    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLP =
823            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
824                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
825                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
826                    "#else\n" +
827                    "#define LOWP \n" +
828                    "#endif\n" +
829                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
830                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
831                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
832                    partialCodeHSL +
833                    "void main()\n" +
834                    "{\n" +
835                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
836                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
837                    "   hsl.xy = vec2(cos(hsl.x * 6.2831853), sin(hsl.x * 6.2831853)) * hsl.y;\n" +
838                    "   vec3 tint = vec3(cos(v_color.x * 6.2831853) * v_color.y, sin(v_color.x * 6.2831853) * v_color.y, v_color.z);\n" +
839                    "   hsl.xyz = mix(hsl.xyz, tint, v_color.w);\n" +
840                    "   hsl.xy = vec2(fract(atan(hsl.y, hsl.x) / 6.2831853), length(hsl.xy));\n" +
841                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
842                    "}";
843    
844    public static final String fragmentShaderReplacement = 
845                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
846                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
847                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
848                    "#else\n" +
849                    "#define LOWP \n" +
850                    "#endif\n" +
851                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
852                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
853                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
854                    "uniform vec4 u_search;\n" +
855                    "uniform vec4 u_replace;\n" +
856                    "void main()\n" +
857                    "{\n" +
858                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n" +
859                    "   float curve = smoothstep(0.0, 1.0, 1.25 - distance(tgt.rgb, u_search.rgb) * 2.0);\n" +
860                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4(mix(tgt.rgb, u_replace.rgb, curve), tgt.a) * v_color;\n" +
861                    "}";
862    /**
863     * A drop-in replacement for the default fragment shader that eliminates lightness differences in the output colors.
864     * Specifically, it does the normal SpriteBatch shader's step with the multiplicative batch color, converts to IPT,
865     * sets intensity to 0.5, shrinks the P and T components so the color is less saturated, and then converts back to
866     * an RGBA color. Editing this shader is strongly encouraged to fit your needs!
867     * <br>
868     * This uses {@link #vertexShader}, as usual.
869     * @see #fragmentShaderConfigurableContrast a per-sprite-configurable version of this
870     */
871    public static String fragmentShaderFlatLightness =
872  "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
873  "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
874  "precision mediump float;\n" +
875  "#else\n" +
876  "#define LOWP \n" +
877  "#endif\n" +
878  "#define TARGET_LIGHTNESS 0.5 \n" +
879  "#define SATURATION_CHANGE 1.0 \n" +
880  "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
881  "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
882  "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
883  "void main()\n" +
884  "{\n" +
885  "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
886  "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
887  "         * (tgt.rgb * v_color.rgb));\n" +
888  "    ipt.x = TARGET_LIGHTNESS;\n" + // change to desired lightness or pass in a lightness as a uniform
889  "//    ipt.x = (ipt.x - 0.5) * 0.25 + TARGET_LIGHTNESS;\n" + // an alternative way that preserves a tiny bit of original lightness
890  "    ipt.yz *= SATURATION_CHANGE;\n" + // multiplies saturation by SATURATION_CHANGE, which may be more or less than 1.0
891  "    vec3 back = clamp(mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
892  "    gl_FragColor = vec4(back, v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
893  "}";
894    /**
895     * A specialized shader that can reduce lightness differences in the output colors, saturate/desaturate them, and
896     * can be configured to use some of the existing lightness in the image to add to a main flat lightness.
897     * Specifically, it takes the fragment color (typically a pixel in a texture), converts to IPT, does a calculation
898     * involving the intensity of the fragment color where the batch color's blue channel affects how much that
899     * intensity is used, adds the red channel of the batch color, multiplies the P and T components by the green
900     * channel times 2.0 to saturate or desaturate, and then converts back to an RGBA color. The neutral value for this
901     * is the RGBA color 0.5, 0.5, 1.0, 1.0 . A typical usage to achieve a fog effect would be to raise lightness (r),
902     * slightly reduce saturation (g), sharply flatten the original texture's lightness (b), and leave alpha alone (a):
903     * 0.7, 0.4, 0.2, 1.0 .
904     * <br>
905     * This uses {@link #vertexShader}, as usual.
906     * @see #fragmentShaderFlatLightness if you only need one contrast setting and still want to set color tints
907     */
908    public static String fragmentShaderConfigurableContrast =
909            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
910                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
911                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
912                    "#else\n" +
913                    "#define LOWP \n" +
914                    "#endif\n" +
915                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
916                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
917                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
918                    "void main()\n" +
919                    "{\n" +
920                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
921                    "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
922                    "         * tgt.rgb);\n" +
923                    "    ipt.x = (ipt.x - 0.5) * v_color.b + v_color.r;\n" + // preserves some lightness based on b, sets main lightness with r
924                    "    ipt.yz *= v_color.g * 2.0;\n" + // the green channel affects saturation; if it's 0.5 it won't change saturation.
925                    "    vec3 back = clamp(mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
926                    "    gl_FragColor = vec4(back, v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
927                    "}";
928
929    /**
930     * A day/night cycle shader that can be used without any other parts of this library. This only needs setting the
931     * uniform {@code u_timeOfDay} to any float; the rate at which you change this float affects how fast the day/night
932     * cycle occurs. This is meant to be used with {@link #fragmentShaderDayNight}. Together, they make the color
933     * adjustment go from bluish and dark at night, to purplish at dawn, to orange/yellow and bright at mid-day, toward
934     * red at dusk, and then back to bluish at night.
935     */
936    public static String vertexShaderDayNight = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
937            + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
938            + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
939            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
940            + "uniform float u_timeOfDay;\n"
941            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
942            + "varying vec4 v_tweak;\n"
943            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
944            + "varying float v_lightFix;\n"
945            + "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n"
946            + "\n"
947            + "void main()\n"
948            + "{\n"
949            + "   float st = sin(1.5707963 * sin(0.2617994 * u_timeOfDay));\n"
950            + "   float ct = sin(1.5707963 * cos(0.2617994 * u_timeOfDay));\n"
951            + "   float dd = ct * ct;\n"
952            + "   v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
953            + "   v_color.w = v_color.w * (255.0/254.0);\n"
954            + "   vec3 oklab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *"
955            + "     pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n"
956            + "     * (v_color.rgb * v_color.rgb), forward);\n"
957            + "   v_color.x = clamp(oklab.x + (0.0625 * st), 0.0, 1.0);\n"
958            + "   v_color.yz = clamp(oklab.yz + vec2(0.0625 * dd + 0.03125 * st, 0.1 * st), -1.0, 1.0) * ((dd + 0.25) * 0.5);\n"
959            + "   v_tweak = vec4(0.2 * st + 0.5);\n"
960            + "   v_tweak.w = pow((1.0 - 0.125 * st), 1.709);\n"
961            + "   v_lightFix = 1.0 + pow(v_tweak.w, 1.41421356);\n"
962            + "   v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
963            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
964            + "}\n";
965    /**
966     * The fragment shader counterpart to {@link #vertexShaderDayNight}; must be used with that vertex shader. See its
967     * docs for more info, particularly about the one uniform this needs set.
968     */
969    public static String fragmentShaderDayNight =
970            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
971                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
972                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
973                    "#else\n" +
974                    "#define LOWP \n" +
975                    "#endif\n" +
976                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
977                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
978                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_tweak;\n" +
979                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
980                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
981                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n" +
982                    "void main()\n" +
983                    "{\n" +
984                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
985                    "  vec3 lab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *" +
986                    "             pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n" +
987                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
988                    "  lab.x = clamp(pow(lab.x, v_tweak.w) * v_lightFix * v_tweak.x + v_color.x - 1.0, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
989                    "  lab.yz = clamp((lab.yz * v_tweak.yz + v_color.yz) * 1.5, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
990                    "  lab = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, +0.3963377774, -0.1055613458, -0.0894841775, +0.2158037573, -0.0638541728, -1.2914855480) * lab;\n" +
991                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
992                    "                 mat3(+4.0767245293, -1.2681437731, -0.0041119885, -3.3072168827, +2.6093323231, -0.7034763098, +0.2307590544, -0.3411344290, +1.7068625689) *\n" +
993                    "                 (lab * lab * lab)," +
994                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
995                    "}";
996
997}
